user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit:
```c
int32 OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    memset(token, 0, sizeof(*token));

    /*
     * Confirm that OSAL has been fully initialized before allowing any transactions
     */
    if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_INIT_MAGIC_NUMBER &&
        OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    /*
     * only "exclusive" locks allowed after shutdown request (this is mode used for delete).
     * All regular ops will be blocked.
     */
    if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState == OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER && lock_mode != OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    /*
     * Transactions cannot be started on an object type for which
     * there are no actual objects
     */
    if (OS_GetMaxForObjectType(idtype) == 0)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INVALID_ID;
    }

    token->lock_mode = lock_mode;
    token->obj_type  = idtype;
    token->obj_idx   = OSAL_INDEX_C(-1);

    if (lock_mode != OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE)
    {
        OS_Lock_Global(token);
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: All other lines in the function do not call or pass pointers to the string.h family of functions and therefore are not relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. The conditional checks of OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState, the OS_GetMaxForObjectType(idtype) call, the simple assignments to token->lock_mode, token->obj_type, and token->obj_idx, and the various return statements do not invoke standard string handling functions nor perform raw memory/string operations and thus do not need investigation under this rule. The two fragments reported are the only places in this function that directly invoke a string.h routine (memset) or pass the token pointer to another routine (OS_Lock_Global) that could perform string.h operations and therefore should be investigated for potential out-of-bounds accesses.
